questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents with a new-onset severe headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw pain while chewing. Laboratory investigations reveal ESR 85 mm/hr, CRP 45 mg/L, and mild normochromic anemia. A biopsy of the temporal artery shows panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates and giant cell formation. In the analysis of T cells from the arterial lesion, which cytokines are primarily produced and play a crucial role in disease progression?

A 72-year-old female presents with a new-onset headache, jaw claudication, and visual symptoms. Her ESR is 92 mm/hr and CRP is elevated. Temporal artery biopsy is planned, but immediate treatment is necessary. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait for biopsy results before starting any treatment

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a bilateral lower extremity rash that appeared 2 weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection. He also complains of abdominal pain and joint pain. On examination, there is a symmetrically distributed palpable purpuric rash present over both lower extremities, predominantly on the extensor surfaces. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and image findings?

A 7-year-old boy presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and joint pain. Laboratory studies show normal platelet count with elevated IgA levels. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Renal biopsy is essential for confirming the diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: Glucocorticoids help reduce arthralgias and abdominal discomfort

options.label: C
options.text: Glucocorticoids have not proven benefit in treating skin and renal manifestations

options.label: D
options.text: Complement levels are typically normal in this condition

questions.correct_answer: A. Renal biopsy is essential for confirming the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Criteria

Presence of two or more of the following:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia
  • Patient 20 years or younger at disease onset
  • Bowel angina (diffuse abdominal pain or diagnosis of bowel ischemia)
  • The biopsy showed granulocytes in the walls of small arterioles or venules, and IgA deposits were found in the vessel wall.

Lab Findings
  • Normal complement (Option D ruled out). This is an important distinguishing feature from some other vasculitis.
  • Normal platelets
  • Elevated IgA in ~50%
  • Mild leukocytosis
  • Skin biopsy can confirm (shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition)
  • Renal biopsy is rarely needed (Option A)

Treatment
  • Often self-limiting
  • Glucocorticoids (1 mg/kg/day prednisone): (Option B ruled out)
    • Helpful for: edema, joint pain, abdominal pain
    • Not proven for skin/renal disease (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 19-year-old Asian female presents with persistent malaise, fever, night sweats, and unequal blood pressure readings in both arms (right arm 130/80 mmHg, left arm 100/70 mmHg). ESR is elevated at 85 mm/hr, and MR angiography shows ostial narrowing of the left subclavian artery with pan-arteritis. Which statement describes the pathogenesis and initial management?

options.label: A
options.text: Primarily intimal disease; start anti-TNF therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Panarteritis with intimal proliferation; start prednisone

questions.correct_answer: D. Panarteritis with intimal proliferation; start prednisone

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with fever, rash, and strawberry tongue. The child has circumoral pallor and a sandpaper-like rash. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated inflammatory markers. Which of the following statements is most likely to be true regarding this presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: IVIG with high-dose aspirin is the first-line treatment

options.label: B
options.text: The rash begins over the face and shows circumoral erythema

options.label: C
options.text: Throat culture is essential for diagnosis and Penicillin is the treatment of choice

options.label: D
options.text: Coronary artery involvement is seen in the majority of untreated cases

questions.correct_answer: C. Throat culture is essential for diagnosis and Penicillin is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Feature

Kawasaki’s Disease

Scarlet Fever

Cause

Etiology unknown; Likely Immune-Mediated.

Group A Streptococcus infection (Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins A, B, C).

Age Group Affected
  • It primarily affects children,
  • 80% of cases in children ≤5 years old,
  • Peak incidence at ≤2 years.

Most common in children aged 2–10 years, usually following Group A streptococcal pharyngitis.

Main Symptoms

Based on fever lasting ≥5 days + ≥4 of 5 principal criteria:

  • Fever ≥5 days
  • Bilateral conjunctival injection (red eyes)
  • Oral mucosal changes (strawberry tongue, red lips)
  • Rash (polymorphous)
  • Extremity changes (swelling, redness, peeling)
  • Fever,
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Headache,
  • Characteristic rash with a sandpaper-like texture, beginning on the face, spreading to the trunk and extremities, sparing palms and soles, followed by desquamation.
  • Circumoral pallor, and
  • Strawberry tongue.

Other Symptoms

Coronary artery aneurysms,

myocarditis, pericarditis, myocardial ischemia, infarction, cardiomegaly.

Rash accentuates in skin folds (Pastia’s lines), desquamation in the second week.

Complications
  • Coronary Artery Aneurysms
  • Myocardial Infarction
  • Thrombosis
  • Vasculitis.
  • Rheumatic Fever
  • Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

Diagnostic method

Diagnosis is clinical based on criteria and confirmed by echocardiogram for coronary artery changes.

Throat culture or RADT (Rapid Antigen Detection Test) for Group A Streptococcus confirmation.

Treatment
  • High-dose IV Immunoglobulin and Aspirin to reduce coronary artery complications.
  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be required (e.g., coronary artery bypass grafting).
  • Antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin),
  • Supportive care for fever and throat pain.

questions.text: Match the markers (Column B) with the correct vasculitis (Column A). a. Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) 1. C-ANCA b. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN) 2. P-ANCA 3. Proteinase-3 4. Myeloperoxidase

Feature

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)/ Wegener's granulomatosis

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Key Clinical Features

  • Hematuria

Laboratory Markers

c-ANCA

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with fever, purpura, and arthralgias. Biopsy shows small vessel vasculitis with immune deposits. Lab tests reveal C-ANCA antibodies. Which of the following is most consistent with this clinical picture?

options.label: A
options.text: Microscopic polyangiitis with segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis

options.label: B
options.text: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis

questions.correct_answer: B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis
questions.explanation:
Disease

Key Features

Antibodies/Labs

Pathology

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
  • Pauci-immune vasculitis
  • Upper/lower respiratory
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • PR3-ANCA
  • c-ANCA pattern
  • Granulomatous inflammation
  • Small vessel vasculitis

Microscopic Polyangiitis
  • Pulmonary-renal syndrome
  • No granulomas
  • Segmental necrotizing GN
  • MPO-ANCA
  • p-ANCA pattern
  • (Option A ruled out)
  • Necrotizing vasculitis
  • No granulomas

Churg-Strauss (EGPA)
  • Asthma
  • Peripheral eosinophilia
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • MPO-ANCA
  • p-ANCA pattern
  • (Option C ruled out)
  • Eosinophilic granulomas
  • Vasculitis

Mixed Cryoglobulinemia
  • Often HCV-associated
  • Purpura
  • Arthralgias
  • Cryoglobulins
  • HCV antibodies (Option D ruled out)
  • Immune complex deposits
  • Small vessel vasculitis

Vasculitis Type

Examples of Diseases

Granulomatous
  • Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
  • Churg-Strauss Syndrome
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Behcet's Disease (granulomatous form)

Non-Granulomatous
  • Microscopic Polyangiitis
  • Polyarteritis Nodosa
  • Henoch-Schonlein Purpura
  • Takayasu Arteritis
  • Giant Cell Arteritis
  • Kawasaki Disease

Necrotizing
  • Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
  • Microscopic Polyangiitis
  • Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)
  • Churg-Strauss Syndrome
  • Henoch-Schönlein Purpura

Non-Necrotizing
  • Takayasu Arteritis
  • Giant Cell Arteritis
  • Kawasaki Disease
  • Sarcoidosis (rare vasculitis involvement)

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from Turkey presents with recurrent painful oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and bilateral red eyes. Examination reveals bilateral anterior uveitis and erythema nodosum on his legs. After the needle prick, he develops an erythematous papule in 48 hours. Laboratory studies show elevated IL-1, TNF-α, and increased neutrophil activity. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis and clinical features of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: ANCA-mediated vasculitis with small vessel involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Auto-inflammatory vasculitis with T-cell mediated immunity and neutrophilic inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: Antibody-mediated disease with preferential renal involvement

options.label: D
options.text: IgA-mediated vasculitis with predominant GI manifestations

questions.correct_answer: B. Auto-inflammatory vasculitis with T-cell mediated immunity and neutrophilic inflammation
questions.explanation:
Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • Uveitis (>50%)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and bilateral uveitis. He develops pustules 48 hours after the needle prick. Further examination reveals erythema nodosum and non-erosive arthritis of the knees. Based on clinical criteria, Behcet's Disease is diagnosed. Which of the following represents the most appropriate initial management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: High-dose steroids alone for all manifestations

options.label: B
options.text: Targeted therapy based on organ involvement: colchicine for mucocutaneous, topical steroids for anterior uveitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Targeted therapy based on organ involvement: colchicine for mucocutaneous, topical steroids for anterior uveitis
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria (ITR-ICBD)

Two Points Each:

  • Genital aphthosis
  • Ocular lesions
 

One Point Each:

  • Oral aphthosis
  • Skin lesions
  • Vascular manifestations
  • Positive pathergy

≥3 points needed for diagnosis

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific inflammation markers
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • ESR, CRP elevation
  • Leukocytosis

Helps rule out other conditions

Required Investigations
  • Ophthalmologic examination
  • Pathergy test
  • Skin biopsy if needed
  • Imaging, based on symptoms

Confirms involvement and monitors complications

Treatment

Mucocutaneous Treatment
  • Colchicine 1-2mg/day
  • Topical steroids
  • Topical sucralfate

Refractory: Systemic steroids, azathioprine

Ocular Treatment
  • Anterior: Topical steroids
  • Posterior: Steroids + azathioprine

Refractory: TNF inhibitors

Major Organ Involvement
  • Vascular: High-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide
  • Neurologic: High-dose steroids + immunosuppression

Requires aggressive therapy and monitoring

questions.text: A 4-year-old Asian boy presents with 6 days of fever, bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy >1.5 cm. On day 7, he develops erythema of palms and soles. Laboratory studies show elevated TNF-α and pro-BNP. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct viral invasion of coronary vessels with late thrombosis

options.label: B
options.text: Immune-mediated medium vessel vasculitis with coronary artery predilection

options.label: C
options.text: Bacterial toxin-mediated endothelial damage with early thrombosis

options.label: D
options.text: Primary autoimmune arteritis with small vessel involvement

questions.correct_answer: B. Immune-mediated medium vessel vasculitis with coronary artery predilection
questions.explanation:
Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Diagnostic Criteria (CREAM)

Fever for >= 5 days + 4 out of 5 criteria (CREAM)

C: Conjunctivitis (bilateral, non-purulent)

R: Rash (polymorphous)

E: Extremity changes (swelling, redness, peeling)

A: Adenopathy (cervical >1.5cm)

M: Mucosal changes (strawberry tongue)

Needs 4/5 criteria + fever ≥5 days

High-Risk Features

- Male gender

- Age <1 year

- Asian ethnicity

- Fever >8 days

- High pro-BNP

Higher risk of coronary complications

Cardiac Involvement

- Coronary artery aneurysms

- Myocarditis

- Pericardial effusion

15-25% develop aneurysms if untreated

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with 6 days of fever, bilateral conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, and polymorphous rash. Initial labs show elevated CRP, ESR, and thrombocytosis. Which of the following represents the most appropriate initial diagnostic test and treatment strategy?

options.label: B
options.text: Echocardiogram and IVIG 2g/kg plus high-dose aspirin

questions.correct_answer: B. Echocardiogram and IVIG 2g/kg plus high-dose aspirin
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Clinical Significance

Initial Diagnostic Tests

1. Echocardiogram

2. Labs:

- CRP (typically >3 mg/dL)

- ESR (typically >40 mm/hr)

- CBC: Leukocytosis >15,000

- Platelets >450,000

- Albumin <3.0 g/dL

- Elevated ALT

- Sterile pyuria

- Echo: baseline coronary status

- ≥3 supplemental labs support diagnosis in incomplete KD

- Helps differentiate from other febrile illnesses

Initial Treatment

1. IVIG:

- 2g/kg single dose

- Within 10 days of fever

2. Aspirin:

- High-dose (80-100mg/kg/d)

- Until afebrile 48h

- Reduces aneurysm risk

- IVIG resistance in 15-20%

- Time-sensitive intervention

Additional Therapy

- Second IVIG dose if needed

- Steroids in high-risk cases

- Infliximab for refractory cases

- Anticoagulation if aneurysms

- Based on response

- Risk stratification

- Prevent complications

Follow-up

- Echo at 2 weeks

- Echo at 6-8 weeks

- Low-dose aspirin (3-5mg/kg/d)

- Long-term cardiac monitoring

- Monitor for aneurysms

- Assess treatment response

- Prevent thrombosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of asthma presents with worsening dyspnea, peripheral neuropathy, and palpable purpura on his lower limbs. He also has a history of sinusitis. Blood tests reveal marked eosinophilia and a positive p-ANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following vasculitis syndromes is not classified as an ANCA-associated vasculitis according to the Chapel Hill Classification?
questions.explanation:
Revised Chapel Hill classification of vasculitis syndromes
Large vessel vasculitis
  • Takayasu arteritis
  • Giant cell arteritis

Medium vessel vasculitis

 

  • Takayasu arteritis
  • Giant cell arteritis
Small vessel vasculitis (SVV)
  • Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)–associated vasculitis
    • Microscopic polyangiitis
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s)
    • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss)
  • Immune complex SVV
    • Anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease
    • Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
    • IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein)
    • Hypocomplementemic urticarial vasculitis (anti-C1q vasculitis)
Variable vessel vasculitis
  • Behcet’s disease
  • Cogan’s syndrome
Single-organ vasculitis
  • Cutaneous leukocytoclastic angiitis
  • Cutaneous arteritis
  • Primary central nervous system vasculitis Isolated aortitis

Vasculitis associated with systemic disease
  • Lupus vasculitis
  • Rheumatoid vasculitis
  • Sarcoid vasculitis
Vasculitis associated with probable etiology
  • Hepatitis C virus–associated cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
  • Hepatitis B virus–associated vasculitis
  • Syphilis-associated aortitis
  • Drug-associated immune complex vasculitis
  • Drug-associated ANCA-associated vasculitis
  • Cancer-associated vasculitis
